name: Oman
description: Oman, a sultanate nestled on the southeastern coast of the Arabian Peninsula, boasts a diverse landscape ranging from towering mountains and dramatic wadis to vast deserts and pristine coastline. Rich in history and culture, Oman offers a unique blend of traditional Bedouin life and modern development. Its strategic location has shaped its identity, fostering trade and cultural exchange for centuries.

quickFacts.label: Population
quickFacts.description: The population of Oman is primarily comprised of Omani Arabs, with a significant expatriate community.
quickFacts.detail: The majority of the population resides in urban centers like Muscat, Salalah, and Sohar.

quickFacts.label: Capital
quickFacts.description: Muscat is the political, economic, and cultural center of Oman.
quickFacts.detail: It's a modern city with a historic old town (Al-Rimal) and a vibrant waterfront.

quickFacts.label: Area
quickFacts.description: Oman is the fifth-largest country in the Arabian Peninsula.
quickFacts.detail: It's roughly the size of the UK.

quickFacts.label: Official Language
quickFacts.description: Omani Arabic is the official language, with some regional dialects.
quickFacts.detail: English is widely spoken, particularly in business and tourism.

quickFacts.label: Currency
quickFacts.description: The Omani Rial is pegged to the US dollar.
quickFacts.detail: Exchange rates fluctuate slightly, but generally remain stable.

quickFacts.label: GDP
quickFacts.description: Oman's economy is driven by oil and gas, tourism, and fisheries.
quickFacts.detail: Diversification efforts are underway to reduce reliance on hydrocarbons.

climateData.title: Oman's Climate
climateData.description: Oman experiences a hot desert climate with significant seasonal variations. The coastal areas enjoy milder temperatures, while the interior is extremely hot during the summer. Rainfall is concentrated during the winter months.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Summer (June - August)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: This is Oman’s hottest period, with temperatures soaring to 45°C (113°F) or higher in the interior.  The coastal areas are still warm, around 35-40°C (95-104°F).

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Autumn (September - November)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Temperatures begin to moderate, with daytime highs averaging around 30-35°C (86-95°F). Rainfall increases, particularly in the western mountains.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Winter (December - February)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Winters are mild and relatively wet, with average daytime temperatures ranging from 18-22°C (64-72°F). The northern mountains receive significant snowfall.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Spring (March - May)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Temperatures rise again, with average daytime highs around 28-32°C (82-90°F). The landscape comes alive with greenery and blooming flowers.

naturalWonders.name: Jebel Akhdar (Green Mountain)
naturalWonders.description: Jebel Akhdar, meaning 'Green Mountain', is a dramatic mountain range in the northwest of Oman, characterized by terraced farms, lush greenery, and stunning views. It's a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The area is renowned for its unique microclimate, which allows for the cultivation of fruits and vegetables at high altitudes. Traditional Omani villages cling to the mountainsides, offering a glimpse into a bygone era.
viewingTips: Wear layers as temperatures can fluctuate

scientificData.Altitude: High altitude, creating a unique climate

naturalWonders.name: Wadi Shab
naturalWonders.description: Wadi Shab is a stunning wadi (canyon) located in the south of Oman, known for its crystal-clear turquoise pools and towering cliffs. It's a popular destination for swimming and hiking.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: The wadi requires a short hike through rocky terrain and wading through shallow water to reach the main pools. The final pool is a hidden oasis surrounded by lush vegetation.
viewingTips: Bring a waterproof bag for valuables

scientificData.Erosion: Erosion by flash floods has shaped the wadi's dramatic landscape

naturalWonders.name: The Empty Quarter (Rub' al Khali)
naturalWonders.description: The Empty Quarter, also known as Rub' al Khali, is the largest continuous sand desert in the world, stretching across southern Oman and Yemen. It's a vast, desolate landscape of towering dunes and shifting sands.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: Exploring the Empty Quarter requires specialized equipment and experienced guides. The area is known for its extreme temperatures and challenging terrain. It offers a unique opportunity to experience the raw beauty of the Arabian Peninsula.
viewingTips: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen

scientificData.Sand Dune Height: Dunes can reach heights of up to 30 meters (100 feet)

biodiversityCategory.name: Marine Biodiversity
biodiversityCategory.description: Oman's coastline is home to a rich and diverse marine ecosystem, supporting a wide range of fish, coral, and marine mammals.

statistics.details: The coral reefs of Oman are home to a variety of colorful fish, invertebrates, and algae.
Oman's waters support a diverse range of fish, including tuna, grouper, and barracuda.

notableSpecies.name: Hawksbill Turtle
notableSpecies.significance: A key indicator of marine ecosystem health.

notableSpecies.name: Dugong
notableSpecies.significance: A gentle marine mammal that grazes on seagrass.

ecosystemData.title: Oman's Ecosystems
ecosystemData.overview: Oman’s ecosystems are incredibly diverse, ranging from arid deserts and rugged mountains to lush wadis and coastal marine environments. These ecosystems support a wide array of plant and animal life, many of which are endemic to the region.

conservationStatus.protectedAreas: Approximately 15% of Oman’s land area is protected within national parks and reserves.

biodiversityCategories.name: Desert Ecosystems
biodiversityCategories.description: Dominated by sand dunes, rocky plateaus, and sparse vegetation, these ecosystems are adapted to extreme heat and aridity.

statistics.details: Many plants are drought-resistant and have deep root systems.

notableSpecies.name: Desert Fox
notableSpecies.significance: A nocturnal predator adapted to desert life.

biodiversityCategories.name: Coastal Ecosystems
biodiversityCategories.description: Oman’s coastline is characterized by diverse habitats, including coral reefs, mangroves, seagrass beds, and rocky shores.

statistics.details: Mangroves provide important habitat for fish and other marine life.

notableSpecies.name: Oman Damselfish
notableSpecies.significance: A unique species found only in Oman's coastal waters.

activities.title: Outdoor Activities in Oman
activities.description: Oman offers a wide range of outdoor activities for all levels of experience, from hiking and camping to water sports and cultural tours.

activityCategories.name: Hiking
activityCategories.description: Explore Oman’s stunning mountains, wadis, and coastal trails.

activities.name: Jebel Akhdar Hike
activities.description: Hike through the terraced farms and villages of Jebel Akhdar.

activities.name: Wadi Shab Hike
activities.description: Hike through the wadi to reach the hidden pools.

activityCategories.name: Water Sports
activityCategories.description: Enjoy swimming, snorkeling, diving, and kayaking in Oman’s pristine waters.

activities.name: Snorkeling in Bandar Al Juthrah
activities.description: Explore the vibrant coral reefs and marine life of Bandar Al Juthrah.

activities.name: Diving in the Straits of Hormuz
activities.description: Dive among shipwrecks and diverse marine ecosystems in the Straits of Hormuz.

clothing.summer: Lightweight, breathable clothing, swimwear, hat, sunglasses
clothing.winter: Layers of clothing, including a jacket, sweater, and long pants
clothing.yearRound: Comfortable walking shoes, sunscreen, insect repellent

equipment.hiking: Hiking boots, trekking poles, map, compass
